analytic.title: Visual Memory for Natural Scenes

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Humans have been exposed to a continuous stream of scenes since the first day of life. Through constant processing and encoding of scenes, the human brain develops scene knowledge that aids current scene understanding and guides future scene memory and decision-making. In this chapter, we will discuss how humans' scene memories and understandings are shaped by (1) scene-level properties that are intrinsic to a scene or that arise through comparisons, (2) observer-level properties, such as prior knowledge, cognitive states, and ages, and (3) new knowledge generated through the interactions between scene-and observer level information. Key points: • Visual memories of natural scenes are often studied using static scene images, artificial navigation games, or through scene imagination. • Regardless of individual differences, people consistently remember certain scenes better than others (the memorability effect). • Objects that are semantically congruent with a scene or visually salient within a scene tend to be better remembered but may also be falsely remembered. • People show transformations of boundary information after viewing a scene (boundary distortion), which is driven by general expectations about scene composition. • Experts in certain areas (e.g., arts, hiking, and navigation) process scenes differently and encode different aspects of scenes from area novices. • Children go through infantile and childhood amnesia, where they are able to encode scenes during infancy and childhood, but these memories are mostly forgotten by adulthood. • Scene images have been used to diagnose cognitive decline and dementia. • Humans can encode environments from both egocentric and allocentric viewpoints starting from infancy, and hippocampal neural development facilitates the more flexible use of scene memory. • During spatial navigation, visual scene information and internal knowledge constantly interact to construct and update cognitive maps, which can be used to guide route planning.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Perceiving, remembering, and navigating a scene requires the integration of external visual information coming from the world and internal information stemming from previous memories. Imagine walking into a new grocery store you have never been to and trying to pick up some blueberries. If you first see vegetables in your field of vision, based on the memory of previous grocery stores that you have been to, you may realize that blueberries should be located nearby because vegetable and fruit sections are usually adjacent. In this process of seeking blueberries in a new grocery store, you use external landmarks (i.e., vegetables) and consult internal memories of familiar grocery store layouts (i.e., vegetables and fruits are adjacent). Such ongoing integration between external information in the vision field and internal information from previous scene memories is fundamental for humans to understand, encode, and behave adaptively (e.g., avoid obstacles, plan optimal routes, etc.) in a scene. Scenes are thus special and interesting stimuli to study not only because they are ubiquitous and essential in humans' lives, but also because they contain rich information (e.g., spatial relations, object occurrences, etc.) beyond other frequently studied image stimuli (e.g., faces, objects, textures, etc.). As a result, there is incredible nuance in how such rich information within scenes interacts with observers' personal experiences in affecting memory. In this chapter, we discuss how visual memory for natural scenes is affected by external (scene-specific) and internal (observer-specific) factors, and how the integration of external and internal processes gives rise to adaptive behaviors. Before we are able to consider memory, we must first develop clear definitions of scenes and see how scene components affect scene processing. Natural scenes consist of multiple objects with spatial relations that derive meaning. Henderson and Hollingworth's (1999) seminal paper defines a scene as "a semantically coherent (and often namable) view of a real-world environment comprising background elements and multiple discrete objects arranged in a spatially licensed manner." Based on this definition, in order to understand and memorize a visual scene, humans need to first recognize individual objects in the scene and how these objects are positioned in relation to one another. Upon such initial perception, humans can then draw multifaceted inferences about the scene, including the scene's category (e.g., indoor vs. outdoor, nature vs. manmade) and spatial location, what actions can be performed in the scene, how to navigate the scene, etc. When making scene inferences based on the scene's objects and object relations, observers show different understanding due to different prior knowledge. On the one hand, observers may draw different inferences about the same objects when they are organized differently (i.e., different spatial relations between objects). For example, a scene that shows vegetables and fruits being displayed in different sections may indicate a grocery store, whereas another scene that shows the same vegetables and fruits being displayed in a mixed manner may capture a farmers' market. On the other hand, the same organization of objects may lead to different inferences across observers because of different prior experiences. For example, when looking at a map, experienced drivers may intentionally plan for faster routes by taking more turns to avoid busy locations (e.g., schools and malls), while inexperienced drivers may plan for straight routes until they need to take turns. In other words, both object organizations within a scene and the observer's previous experiences affect what information is garnered and subsequently encoded from a scene. In the next three paragraphs, we will take a closer look at how humans understand scenes through processing scene properties, recalling existing knowledge, and integrating information coming from scenes and prior memory. Humans readily understand scenes by processing the scenes' informative regions and visual statistics. Even with a glimpse, observers quickly and automatically make inferences based on scene properties that give rise to a gist representation of the scene, including the processing of low-level and high-level scene features (Oliva, 2005). Observers may utilize the scenes' lowlevel features, such as colors, densities of edges, and spatial frequencies (repeated structures), to infer whether a scene depicts an indoor or outdoor space and whether a scene is natural or manmade (Berman et al., 2014;Loschky & Larson, 2008, 2010Zhang, 2017). Observers may also utilize high-level scene features, such as objects and image semantics (e.g., the location depicted in the scene), to predict feasible events or movements within a scene (Bonner & Epstein, 2017). Prior work highlights that humans' attention toward a scene is mainly guided by its high-level rather than low-level features (Henderson et al., 2019). This suggests that observers are sensitive to informative scene regions that drive the scene's meaning. Before viewing a scene, observers hold expectations of what objects should go where (i.e., scene grammar), developed from previously encountered object co-occurrences (Võ, 2021). Through processing low-and high-level features, observers can easily label a scene when informative scene regions contain object spatial relations that align with expectations about this scene label. For example, you may quickly realize that a scene depicts a produce-selling location if you see a juxtaposing display of various vegetables and fruits, each grouped with its same kind (Figure 1a), as such a fruit organization aligns with your expectation of what a produce-selling area should look like. In contrast, when randomizing the spatial relations between items of the same kind (Figure 1b), it becomes more difficult to label this scene because informative spatial relations are stripped away. These studies demonstrate that high-and low-level information intrinsic to scene stimuli affects scene representations at perception, which are then further processed into memory. This chapter is organized into three parts, with the first two introducing external and internal factors that affect scene memory and the third weaving these factors together to depict how humans utilize such bi-directional information in facilitating real-world behaviors. As shown in Figure 2, Section 2 (purple) of this chapter introduces external, stimulus-level factors that affect scene processing and encoding, including factors intrinsic to a specific scene (intra-stimulus properties, see Section 2.1) and factors originating from cross-scene comparisons (inter-stimulus properties, see Section 2.2). Section 3 (green) presents internal, individual-level factors that affect scene encoding, including memories acquired before encoding, cognitive states during encoding, and age. Section 4 (orange) then discusses how stimulus-level and individual-level information interact during encoding to enable the construction of cognitive maps, which are used to guide subsequent scene encoding and physical movements. Finally, the chapter ends with a summary (Section 5) of current knowledge and unanswered questions in the field of memory of natural scenes. In sum, this chapter aims to facilitate the thinking about memory encoding processes as a continuous communication between the external and internal world. Throughout this chapter, we will focus on scene encoding rather than retrieval because memory retrieval mechanisms remain understudied and controversial. It is still under debate how much the representations of information between encoding and memory retrieval differ. At memory retrieval, it is supposed that the reactivation of the same neural activity patterns instantiated during visual perception would bring back the same scene in mind (i.e., mental imagery) (Dijkstra et al., 2019). However, recent work suggests that neural patterns undergo certain spatial transformations between visual encoding and retrieval of scenes Favila et al., 2020). In addition, memory retrieval requires triggers such as cues or free recall, while memory encoding happens more spontaneously after visual perception. For these reasons, we will discuss the encoding process of visual scenes from here on. Figure 2. An overview of the main topics that this chapter will cover. Section 2 (purple) will introduce the effects of external, scene-intrinsic properties on scene memory processing. Section 3 (green) will discuss the effects of internal, observer-specific factors on scene memory processing. Section 4 (orange) will discuss how the external and internal factors interact to create cognitive maps and enable spatial navigation. The faded scene images in the background depict different views of grocery stores, where the top image illustrates an egocentric view of an observer standing on the ground, and the bottom image represents an allocentric (aerial) view of what the observer may construct in mind to store the grocery store layout. (Background images have Creative Commons licenses from Google) 2. External (Stimulus-Level) Effects on Visual Memory of Natural Scenes This section discusses a selection of external visual factors originating from scene stimuli that affect scene encoding. The first half of this section focuses on visual information within each scene, highlighting three common scene properties that affect memory: scene grammar, saliency, and memorability. Because humans are constantly exposed to a continuous stream of scenes in real life, a scene's memory can be affected by its context. Thus, the second half of this section explores how similarities between scenes and a scene's context affect a scene's memory.

2.1.Intra-stimulus properties 2.1.1. Alignment with scene grammar When specific objects and object organizations violate expectations of a scene, observers show worse memories, but not always. Such scene expectation of what objects should go where is called the "scene grammar," which is developed through experience (Võ, 2021). Öhlschläger & Võ (2020) suggest that scene grammar is developed from scene schema (see Section 3.1.1. Schema) and can eventually become part of the schema, which contains general knowledge about the spatial representations of a scene and possible actions or events that can happen in a scene. The field has not explicitly differentiated the two terms, but it seems scene grammar indicates scene-specific characteristics and abnormalities (e.g., there is a fork in a specific bathroom scene), whereas scene schema represents commonalities for a kind of scene (e.g., bathrooms usually do not have forks). With a preexisting scene grammar in mind, one can infer the meaning of a scene (scene semantics) by identifying individual objects (the "what"), their locations (the "where"), and their relational structures (scene syntax). In other words, understanding a scene entails grasping object identity, location, and spatial relations. As exemplified in our grocery store example in Figure 1, observers can infer a scene's meaning (i.e., a produce-selling area) based on object organizations within the scene. As scene grammar affects scene processing by guiding eye movements (Võ & Wolfe, 2015), violating scene grammar can negatively affect scene perception and memory. Prior work confirms that violating scene grammar leads to worse memory in a scene construction task, even when such violations are intentionally induced by the observers during encoding (Draschkow & Võ, 2017). Specifically, observers show worse recall of object and object location for scenes violating (vs. conforming to) their scene grammar (e.g., putting a toothbrush next to a toilet rather than a sink), even when they spend a longer time interacting with scenes that contain scene-grammar violations. In line with this work, another study shows that when the scene background (e.g., wall) is removed, the scenes that better preserve objects' spatial and size information led to better object recall across tasks (Josephs et al., 2016). These studies show that the preservation of object spatial information in alignment with a common scene grammar promotes the memory of details within the scene. However, recent findings suggest that scene grammar violation may not lead to worse memory for all components of the scene equally, potentially due to differences in task paradigms. In a drawing study where participants draw scene images from memory, they recall more images that contain an object violating scene semantics (e.g., a microscope next to a pool) than those that contain congruent objects (e.g., a microscope in a lab space) (Bainbridge, Kwok, et al., 2021). However, observers' attention is so drawn towards the salient object, which violates the scene grammar, that its surrounding objects (but not the violating object itself) are recalled with fewer details. In other words, observers tend to spotlight their attention on the violating object and thus not spend as many resources on encoding the surrounding semantically coherent objects in the scene. Therefore, knowledge of scene grammar equips humans with sensitivity to certain scene structures and facilitates attention at scene viewing. In addition, when viewing an old scene, people rely more on scene grammar rather than episodic memory to guide their visual search (Draschkow et al., 2014;Võ & Wolfe, 2012). This way, scene grammar affects the memory of scenes not only through facilitating visual attention during object search, but also through providing a scaffold for memories of previously searched objects. These results show that scene grammar violations may take up additional cognitive resources to process, but whether they lead to worse memory is task-dependent and object-specific. Human's sensitivity to scene grammar may be traced back to the brain's tendency to process spatial relations between objects, even when the objects are unnameable, the object structures are artificial, and certain spatial relations are task-irrelevant. EEG data demonstrates that the brain picks up violations of scene grammar early during scene processing (Draschkow et al., 2018). This suggests that objects and object relations are quickly represented during perception. Indeed, object-related image properties that help determine scene configurations, such as object presence and object position, are more quickly encoded into visual memory than surface image properties (e.g., color) (Aginsky et al., 2000). The processing of item associations within a scene is so important to visual processing that scene-selective brain regions are recruited for associative processing of non-scene images (a four-by-four grid containing three artificial shapes, each taking up its own grid location) in an fMRI study (Aminoff & Tarr, 2015). These studies demonstrate that object structures within a scene readily affect scene memory. Another fMRI study suggests that not only the spatial relations between objects within a scene affect memory, but also the task-irrelevant immediate surroundings where the observers view the scene (Chaisilprungraung & Park, 2021). The OPA processes whether a scene is viewed from outside or inside a room through windows. Therefore, it is likely that both the scene grammar within the scene stimuli and the scene grammar in the observers' physical surroundings affect scene encoding. The brain is adept at extracting spatial relationships between objects, both within scene images and from the immediate physical surroundings, and memory is susceptible to the influence of object relations regardless of intentional encoding.

2.1.2. Saliency When thinking of a grocery store, you may more readily recall scenes of the flower section than the bread section, despite purchasing more bread than flowers, because flowers more readily capture people's attention due to their salient colors or locations (close to the entrance where everyone sees them). An object containing contrastive perceptual properties to the rest of a scene pops out from the scene at viewing even within a glimpse (Borji et al., 2013;Itti, 2005). In general, saliency is context-dependent (relative saliency), such that flowers can appear salient in a grocery market but not as salient in a farm (Itti & Koch, 2001), though there can be some objects (e.g., weapons) that are consistently salient across contexts (absolute saliency). Salient objects have been shown to affect visual working memory, such that object details (e.g., identity, location) of more salient objects within a scene are better recalled (Constant & Liesefeld, 2021;Fine & Minnery, 2009). Prior work suggests that salient objects are more readily encoded because they attract visual attention, even though observers do not seem to spend longer looking at the salient objects within a scene (Fine & Minnery, 2009). One study adjusts object saliency by slightly modulating the focus of an image, so that a certain object becomes more salient and observers can more quickly fixate on this object (Veas et al., 2011). Although the change of focus is hard to notice even when the original and modulated images are presented side by side, observers are more likely to recall an object from long-term memory when it is presented in the modulated image, where the object appears to be more salient and more readily captures attention (Parkhurst et al., 2002). Therefore, salient aspects within scenes are prioritized in processing and memory as they attract attention. Interestingly, the memory benefits of scene saliency can be overridden by scene grammar violations (see the previous section). Preexisting knowledge of scene grammar (i.e., what objects should go where within a scene) interacts with the scene's saliency to affect its representation in the human brain (Torralba et al., 2006). An fMRI visual search study shows that while the primary visual cortex (V1) mainly encodes bottom-up perceptual information, visual area V2 mainly represents top-down knowledge, and visual area hV4 is where the bottom-up and topdown information converge (Melloni et al., 2012). In this process, top-down knowledge seems to predominantly affect memory, compared to saliency. Prior work has identified neural underpinnings of visual saliency facilitating visual-spatial memory of objects within a scene. Nevertheless, when an object is out of a scene context (e.g., a vacuum in a bathtub), violating scene semantics, participants have difficulty recognizing the object's location even when this object has maximum salience within the scene (Santangelo et al., 2015). In other words, saliency is less likely to affect spatial memory when knowledge of scene grammar is violated. Although saliency and semantics interplay to affect the memory of natural scenes (Santangelo, 2015), scene semantics may play a more predominant role than saliency in directing attention during viewing of a new scene (Henderson & Hayes, 2017).

2.1.3. Memorability A decade of research has confirmed that there are certain scenes intrinsically more memorable than others. More precisely, regardless of individual differences in memory performance, humans show remarkable consistency in the scene images that they tend to remember and forget, owing to intrinsic image properties-a phenomenon called the memorability effect (Isola et al., 2011). Note that whereas memory indicates observer-specific memory performance, memorability measures image-specific memory across observers. Prior fMRI work has identified dissociable neural substrates for subject-specific memory (frontal and parietal areas) and imageevoked memorability (the ventral visual stream (VVS) and medial temporal lobe (MTL)) (Bainbridge et al., 2017). Magnetoencephalography (MEG) data resonates with the fMRI findings, such that memorability information can be identified from the MEG signal at a timepoint between early vision and memory encoding processes (Khaligh-Razavi et al., 2016;Mohsenzadeh et al., 2019). Hence, image-intrinsic properties that drive the memorability effect are processed during scene perception, which continues to affect scene encoding. An imagespecific memorability score is generally measured in a memory experiment, where observers judge images that they previously encoded as either old or new. The memorability score reflects memory performance, which can be operationalized in several possible ways. How memorable an image is within an image set remains consistent when tested using different groups of observers (Isola et al., 2011;Jeong, 2023;Lu et al., 2020) and is predictable using a deep neural network trained to capture image intrinsic properties (Khosla et al., 2015;Needell & Bainbridge, 2022). The memorability effect, where humans reliably remember certain stimuli better than others, has been robustly shown across age, delay, and experimental paradigm: (1) recent work suggests that children, starting at age four (Guo & Bainbridge, 2023), and adolescents (Almog et al., 2021) remember the same set of scene images as adults; (2) scene images that are consistently better remembered by adults with a short delay (20 minutes) are also better remembered after longer delays (one day or one week) (Goetschalckx et al., 2018); (3) the memorability effect has been robustly measured using various encoding and testing paradigms (Bainbridge, 2020;Bainbridge et al., 2013;Xie et al., 2020), even with surprise memory tests .

It is still ongoing research to investigate what image properties drive memorability, and there has been evidence that high-level scene features better predict scene memorability than low-level features. Isola et al. (2014) took the first attempt to examine a comprehensive list of scene features, including low-level features, such as color properties (e.g., hue, saturation, value) and object statistics (e.g., object counts, object areas, etc.), and high-level features, such as spatial layout (e.g., open, close, cluttered, etc.), human judgments of high-level properties (e.g., aesthetics, interesting, frightening, etc.), and actions (e.g., people walking, sitting, etc.). They found that high-level features mainly drove scene image memorability, which was supported by Kramer and colleagues (2023) who examined the memorability of object images. Specifically, categorical tags of an exhaustive set of namable object images that describe high-level features (e.g., tools, animals, body parts, can sit on, etc.) rather than visual features (e.g., colorful, long, patterned, etc.) significantly predict image memorability scores. In addition, Dubey and colleagues (2015) discovered that a scene's overall memorability is largely affected by its most memorable object. The memorability of certain objects (i.e., people, animals, vehicles) increases when the number of objects within the scene decreases (less cluttered) and when the object is visually salient in an uncluttered scene. This suggests that the amount of variance that object memorability can explain about scene memorability is category-and context-dependent. This result again suggests that high-level features (i.e., objects) drive scene memorability. Researchers have also shown that although low-level features predict memorability in some scenarios (e.g., scene clutter has been shown to correlate with memorability, see Bainbridge et al., 2019), such effects may be due to the reflection of high-level features in low-level features (Schertz & Berman, 2019). To name a couple of examples, a scene's high-level disorder is reflected in lowlevel edge density (i.e., area of edges relative to the scene area), and high-level naturalness is reflected in low-level color features (Kotabe et al., 2016). Therefore, high-level features may have predominantly driven scene memorability, compared to low-level features. Ongoing research using various paradigms reveals that memorable images are more memorable because they may be more efficiently encoded and retrieved. At retrieval, memorable images are less prone to be forgotten in LTM; at encoding, memorable images are more quickly and efficiently processed because they require fewer cognitive resources in visual working memory (VWM) (Gillies et al., 2023). With a very brief glimpse (for 33 ms), observers are better able to categorize a scene image when it is memorable than forgettable, suggesting faster processing of memorable scenes (Goetschalckx, Moors, Vanmarcke, et al., 2019). Another interesting recent study shows that viewing a forgettable scene among memorable ones induces a perception of time slowing down, a proxy of heightened attention, whereas viewing a memorable scene among forgettable ones does not alter time perception (Gedvila et al., 2023). This again emphasizes the efficient processing of memorable images without additional attention efforts. Researchers have suggested that the processing efficiency of memorable images is related to their high-level meaning. Xie et al. (2020) proposed that memorability captures the semantic network, such that more memorable items are located more toward the center of the semantic network. Prior fMRI work supports this notion by showing that memorable scene images evoke more similar neural patterns between one another, compared to forgettable images (Bainbridge & Rissman, 2018), suggesting that the brain represents memorable items closer to one another in the center of cognitive space, whereas forgettable items may be represented more sparsely in the periphery (Lee et al., 2023). Overall, the human brain is highly sensitive to semantic-related, high-level features within a scene and readily decodes memorability before and during scene encoding. In Section 2.1, we discussed properties intrinsic to a scene image, such as spatial relations of objects, saliency, and memorability, that affect visual memory through interacting with the scene's representation in mind. Besides factors intrinsic to individual scene stimuli, factors originating from cross-scene comparisons also affect the visual memory of individual scenes. In Section 2.2, we will discuss three scene properties that affect the memory of episodically relevant scenes or objects: conceptual similarity, perceptual distinctiveness, and a scene's spatial information.

2.2.Inter-stimulus properties 2.2.1. Conceptual similarity After you view a series of beach images, you are more likely to falsely think that you have previously encountered an (in fact, new) image depicting another ocean than a supermarket because "beach" and "ocean" are semantically more similar to each other and can be categorized more closely than "beach" and "supermarket." Such conceptual similarity can affect the visual memory of scene details. It has been shown that scene categorization happens in the ventral visual stream (VVS), including the V1, the PPA, the OPA, the RSC, and the lateral occipital complex (LOC), even when colorful scene images are reduced to line drawings (Musel et al., 2014;Walther et al., 2009Walther et al., , 2011. Interestingly, Collins and Dickerson (2019) showed that scene recognition could be predicted by the functional connectivity between the hippocampus and a scene-selective region in the RSC before and after scene encoding, such that the connectivity prepared the brain to encode information and supported successful encoding. With this, categorical interference between scene images may affect memory throughout the encoding process. The next paragraph will discuss a couple of reasons why conceptually similar scene images can cause more false memories. Although humans can remember a large number of scenes from the same category with details (Brady et al., 2008;Huebner & Gegenfurtner, 2012;Konkle et al., 2010b), as more scenes from the same category are presented, the conceptual similarity between these scenes inevitably reduces and eventually eliminates scene details that one remembers from each scene, resulting in increasing false memories (Lukavský & Děchtěrenko, 2017;Melcher & Murphy, 2011). Note that observers likely have worse memory of object details but not spatial details among conceptually similar (vs. dissimilar) scenes (Hall et al., 2022) because the memory of spatial information remains more resilient across various encoding durations and decay (Megla et al., 2024). Another factor that leads to more false memories is the scene's similarity to its categorical prototype. For example, after viewing a set of beach images, one is more likely to falsely judge having seen an image of a Hawaiian beach with people on the beach (a prototypical beach) than that of an Antarctic beach with penguins on ice (an atypical beach). Prior work discovers that prototypical scenes are more likely to be remembered (Lukavský & Děchtěrenko, 2017), as fMRI data demonstrates that prototypical scenes are more easily categorized at encoding and are associated with better recall (Kuhl et al., 2012). Because scenes more similar to the categorical prototype are closer within a conceptual space (Děchtěrenko et al., 2021), it is possible that when seeing such a similar scene, the representation of the prototypical scene is also partially activated, facilitating the formation of false memories. Overall, the number of conceptually similar scenes and how conceptually similar they are both contribute to the extent of memory interference.

2.2.2. Perceptual distinctiveness A perceptually distinct scene can be better remembered because it contains unique scene details that facilitate the formation of more distinct representations from other scenes. Although scenes from different categories are likely to be perceptually dissimilar, scenes belonging to the same category can also be perceptually distinct (e.g., Hawaiian beach vs. Antarctic beach). In other words, scenes close in a conceptual space tend to be perceptually similar, and less prototypical scenes in a category tend to contain unique perceptual details different from the categorical prototype. Perceptual distinctiveness between scene images is often computed based on lowlevel image features (e.g., color, spatial frequency, etc.; see Goldberger et al., 2003;Huebner & Gegenfurtner, 2012) or human judgments of image similarity (Hout et al., 2014;King et al., 2019). Prior work demonstrates worse recognition performance when a scene is tested with perceptually similar lures, suggesting that visually distinctive details of scenes contribute to visual memory (Huebner & Gegenfurtner, 2012). Notably, when distinctive details (e.g., vegetation, signs, paint scratches on doors) are removed from scene images, observers' recognition accuracy drops from 85% to 20% (Vogt & Magnussen, 2007b). While observers can quickly remember distinct natural scenes with high fidelity, observers' intention to remember and their attention capacity start to play more of a role in memory success when distinctive details are removed (Evans & Baddeley, 2018). There is evidence that visual long-term memory primarily stores the gist of a scene with few object details (Cunningham et al., 2015), such that humans can remember a large number of scenes with low fidelity, but cannot remember a small number of scenes with high fidelity . These results suggest that even though scene details may not be eventually stored in long-term memory, they seem to facilitate encoding nonetheless. In line with this view, the lack of distinctive scene details increases processing difficulty at encoding and the likelihood of subsequent false memory (Guevara Pinto et al., 2020). In general, greater perceptual distinctiveness between different scene stimuli leads to more accurate memory. FMRI work has shown neural signatures of perceptual similarity during the perception and memory of scenes. Similarity judgments of scenes in behavior is decodable from fMRI signals in the PPA, a main area of scene processing (King et al., 2019). Another study discovers that the human brain encodes both the similarity and distinctiveness across scenes for subsequent memory, such that the perirhinal cortex (PRC) and the parahippocampal cortex (PHC) in the medial temporal lobe (MTL) encode similar representations, while the hippocampus encodes distinctive representations across scenes (LaRocque et al., 2013). Objects that appear to be more visually similar have also been found to share more similar neural patterns (Connolly et al., 2012;Edelman et al., 1998;Hiramatsu et al., 2011). This may suggest that a scene image set with low across-item distinctiveness leads to more difficult pattern separation and less efficient encoding. Note that it can be challenging to disentangle the effects of category and perceptual distinctiveness on scene memory because, by nature, scenes that are more conceptually dissimilar are also more perceptually dissimilar. Although both conceptual and perceptual similarity leads to worse memory performance (Huebner & Gegenfurtner, 2012), Konkle and colleagues (2010a) have offered direct evidence that visual long-term memory is more driven by conceptual structure than perceptual distinctiveness across stimuli.

2.2.3. Spatial information When treating a scene as the context of individual objects within the scene, spatial relations in the scene context affect memories of individual objects within the scene. Previously, we mentioned that spatial information is better remembered than object details within a scene (Hall et al., 2022;Megla et al., 2024), suggesting that spatial information may be more deeply processed. In favor of this view, researchers discover that objects are better remembered when encoded in association with scenes than with faces or other objects (Robin & Olsen, 2019). This highlights an idea that spatial information within scenes may provide a scaffold for the memory of object information (Connor & Knierim, 2017). Additionally, human brains seem to prioritize encoding the scenes in object-scene associations. Even when instructed to ignore the scene context, observers always show worse object memories when they encode the object with a scene context, compared to when they encode the object in isolation, regardless of whether the scene context is semantically coherent with the object (Evans & Wolfe, 2022). These findings highlight that a scene's spatial information is so deeply integrated into memory, such that it is resilient to memory decay and may affect the memory of associated object information. Overall, this section elaborated on six scene-specific factors that affect visual memory, including properties intrinsic to each scene and between scenes. Section 2.1 showed that visual memory can be affected by scene grammar violations, object saliency within a scene, and scene-specific memorability. Section 2.2 showed that scene memory can also be affected by how conceptually and perceptually similar its surrounding scenes are, and individual object memory can be affected by its scene context. We will introduce a number of observer-specific factors that affect visual memory in the next section.

div.head: Internal (Individual-Level) Effects on Visual Memory of Natural Scenes
div.p: The previous section walks through external effects on scene memory driven by the scene's intrinsic factors and factors that arise from cross-scene associations. In contrast, this section focuses on factors internal to individual observers. We discuss how the following three internal factors affect visual memory of natural scenes: (1) individual differences in prior experiences, (2) cognitive states during memory, and (3) memory development and decline across the lifespan.

3.1.Prior experience 3.1.1. Schema Across development, humans establish large-scale knowledge systems, or schemas, by extracting commonalities across daily experiences (Gilboa & Marlatte, 2017;Tenenbaum et al., 2011). For example, a person who grows up in a tropical, coastal area may expect beaches to have sand, palm trees, and people in swimsuits. In contrast, another person who grows up in a polar, coastal area may expect beaches to have either sand or ice. In other words, these two people have developed different schemas of a beach's appearance from different prior exposures to beach scenes. Consequently, they will likely show behavioral differences in how they perceive, interpret, and remember new beach scenes, such that a tropical beach scene may be salient to one person but not the other. Specifically, the generic knowledge from schemas in mind helps observers understand, memorize, and retrieve perceptual stimuli like scenes (Graesser & Nakamura, 1982). Individual differences in schema knowledge can lead to slightly different scene grammar representations (see Section 2.1.1. Alignment with scene grammar), as the formation of scene grammar is scaffolded by schemas (Öhlschläger & Võ, 2020). From Section 2.1.1, we know that a scene containing misalignment with scene grammar (e.g., a toilet in the kitchen) affects memory (Bainbridge, Kwok, et al., 2021;Draschkow & Võ, 2017;Josephs et al., 2016). However, there may be individual differences in scene grammar due to varying schemas across people. Observers may have different opinions on how likely an object should be associated with a scene, as a result of holding different schemas in mind. Although some object-scene associations are consistently rated as congruent (e.g., a club car on a golf course) or incongruent (e.g., a panda walking in a mall), others receive more diverse judgments (e.g., a trash can outside of an elevator) (Chen et al., 2022). Prior work shows that both congruency judgments of objects within a scene and the agreement of such judgments across observers affect scene memories. When object-scene associations are rated as more congruent, the scenes are more likely to be recognized and falsely recognized, potentially because the object-scene congruency already exists in prior knowledge and thus can be easily memorized or thought to be memorized. Additionally, compared to object-scene associations that are consistently judged as congruent or incongruent, when object-scene congruency is perceived more differently across observers (i.e., more ambiguous object-scene associations), the associated scene is more easily recognized and falsely recognized (Chen et al., 2022). The authors suggest that ambiguous object-scene pairs may require deeper processing to reconcile with prior schema, resulting in better memory. However, such an interpretation process may introduce more memory intrusion, leading to more false memories. Besides concept-related schema of what objects should co-occur within a scene, action-related schema also affects visual memory. For instance, when a scene depicts a person reading a book, relevant objects (e.g., book, bookshelf) within the scene are more likely to be recalled than irrelevant objects (e.g., plant, bird), but details of irrelevant objects are more likely to be recognized (Goodman, 1980). These results show that the effects of schemas on memory may vary between tasks, but overall, objects and scenes consistent with prior knowledge lead to better memory but also more false memories. In general, prior fMRI work has shown the prefrontal cortex (PFC) and the MTL underlying schema processing (Gilboa & Marlatte, 2017;van Kesteren et al., 2013). One study shows that when an object-scene association is rated more congruent at encoding, there are higher activation in the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) and higher functional connectivity between the mPFC and the VVS, reflecting the function of mPFC in binding the current object-scene pair into an existing schema (van Kesteren et al., 2013). In contrast, when an object-scene association is rated less congruent at encoding, there are higher activation in the MTL, reflecting the integration of a novel object-scene pair into existing schemas. When some prior schema exists but does not perfectly align with a current object-scene pair, the mPFC and the MTL may interact to resolve overlapping and conflicting representations (Gilboa & Marlatte, 2017).

3.1.2. Boundary distortion Prior experience helps develop expectations not only on what objects a scene tends to contain (see the previous section on schema), but also on how far a scene tends to be perceived, which leads to boundary distortions for certain scenes during recall. Specifically, observers consistently recall some scene images with additional information beyond their borders (i.e., boundary extension) and other images without information at their borders (i.e., boundary contraction) (Intraub et al., 1992;Intraub & Richardson, 1989). Lin et al. (2022) empirically proposed that observers make inferences about the depth of a new scene based on a prototypical depth sampled from previously encountered scenes. When the current scene is captured closer to the camera (smaller than the prototypical depth), observers show boundary extension in memory tests, and vice versa. Boundary distortion has shown to be a robust effect across stimulus types (DeLucia & Maldia, 2006), paradigms (Intraub & Dickinson, 2008;Intraub & Richardson, 1989), and age groups (Candel et al., 2004;Chapman et al., 2005;Seamon et al., 2002), but there have been ongoing debates on its underlying mechanism. Earlier work from the past few decades suggests that prior knowledge and schema drive boundary extension of scenes (Intraub, 2012;Intraub et al., 1998;Intraub & Berkowits, 1996), such that the neocortex (Park et al., 2015) and the hippocampus (Chadwick et al., 2013;Mullally et al., 2012) extrapolate information at the scene boundary according to the scene schema during memory processing. However, recent work reveals that boundary extension and contraction appear even when observers copy scene images while viewing them . This suggests that boundary distortion is likely driven by observers' attention patterns at scene viewing rather than memory extrapolation during encoding. Indeed, manipulating attention patterns during encoding (e.g., using certain task paradigms or editing scene images) can affect the extent of boundary distortion. Observers show more boundary contraction from memory when asked to search for specific objects within scenes at encoding (Hall & Geng, 2024) and more boundary extension when encoding edited scenes that appear to be close-ups (Hafri et al., 2022). Recent neural evidence also supports the attention but not the memory account. Patients with hippocampal damage show intact boundary extension, suggesting that the memory effect from schemas may not be necessary for boundary distortion (Kim et al., 2015). In line with this finding, fMRI and ERP work confirms that boundary extension can be decoded during early perception (Chadwick et al., 2013;Czigler et al., 2013). Overall, observers tend to represent scenes at a prototypical distance drawn from previous visual experiences, which leads to boundary distortion of scenes in memory.

3.1.3. Familiarity and expertise Let's revisit the supermarket scene. When you shop at a new supermarket, you may immediately recognize and effortlessly encode novel items not sold at the supermarkets you regularly visit. Such discovery happens automatically because you can fluently process familiar layouts, items, and concepts (e.g., organic, farm-raised, non-GMO, etc.) and leverage cognitive resources to encode the novel aspects. However, imagine someone (e.g., a child or an alien) who is unfamiliar with the setup of supermarkets and has never seen or tasted an apple or heard of organic food labels. This individual needs to direct a large portion of cognitive resources to understand the layout of the supermarket, the items, and the concepts. As a result, they are unlikely to remember as much information from the same visit to the supermarket as an adult from industrialized Western cultures. Prior research has demonstrated this familiarity effect on memories of scenes and face-scene associations. Observers can better remember scene details from images capturing landmarks that they previously visited, compared to scenes depicting novel places (Robin & Moscovitch, 2014). This suggests that encoding familiar contexts takes up fewer cognitive resources, and thus, observers become more cognitively available at encoding scene details. Similarly, encoding associative relations between familiar faces and scenes is less cognitively demanding than encoding relations between unfamiliar ones. Prior fMRI work shows decreased activation in the MTL and the neocortex when an observer encodes familiar (vs. unfamiliar) face-scene associations, suggesting less memory effort for familiar items (Dennis et al., 2015). In addition, item familiarization primarily affects encoding but not retrieval of associations and is decodable before item binding (Elbich et al., 2021;Liu et al., 2017). Therefore, having prior knowledge reduces cognitive demand and directs available resources toward encoding scene details. The accumulation of prior knowledge in a certain area enables domain experts to develop more advanced perceptual and memory patterns of scenes from non-experts. An eye-tracking study discovered that when viewing scenes, artists show more dispersed eye movements covering more details in the scene periphery, whereas artistically untrained observers tend to fixate on a central object (e.g., a human face) (Vogt & Magnussen, 2007a). When tested for scene memory, although artists and artistically untrained observers recalled the same number of scenes, artists correctly remembered more scene details, suggesting that artists might have developed fluency in processing scene details from prior art training and thus show better visual memory of scenes . Such processing fluency effects also hold for expert image analysts viewing aerial scenes (Šikl et al., 2019). Expert image analysts trained to view vertical aerial images (capturing the landscape directly beneath a plane) not only show better memory for vertical aerial images, but also for oblique aerial images (capturing the landscape beneath and slightly in front of a plane by tilting the camera forward), compared to non-experts. This means that domain expertise in analyzing a specific kind of scene may be generalizable and affect memories of similar scenes. Prior knowledge also brings certain details to experts' attention. Hiking experts are more likely to identify and encode hike-related aspects of scenes (e.g., signals related to danger or trail selection), compared to non-expert hikers, while memories of scenes without hike-related details do not differ between groups (Kawamura et al., 2007). In other words, goal-relevant scene details that align with the experts' prior knowledge draw their attention and are prioritized in memory. However, expertise does not always lead to better memory. colleagues (2000, 2006) suggested that London taxi cab drivers may have developed complex spatial representations through extensive navigation experiences at the cost of encoding new spatial memory, as evident by their increased volume in the posterior hippocampus but decreased volume in the anterior hippocampus. In general, expertise allows one to pay more attention to scene details and process scenes more efficiently, which leads to better scene memory.

3.2.Internal (cognitive) state at task Besides observers' prior experience, their cognitive states at task also affect their memory of natural scenes. The following subsections introduce a selection of cognitive and task factors that affect scene memory.

3.2.1. Awareness of upcoming memory tests Being aware of an upcoming memory test during encoding may motivate observers to intentionally memorize scene images. Yet, intentional memorization (explicit memory) does not always outperform incidental memorization (implicit memory), probed using surprised (or incidental) memory tests. For example, implicit memory recall of previously searched objects in a scene search task is better than explicit memory originating from intentional memorization (Draschkow et al., 2014;Josephs et al., 2016). Observers also better recognize scenes that they make aesthetic preference judgments on than those explicitly instructed to be memorized (Choe et al., 2017). Although incidental memorization may outperform intentional memorization under certain task paradigms (Draschkow et al., 2014), prior work suggests that implicit and explicit memories rely on similar encoding processes and representations (Turk-Browne et al., 2006). Eye movement data have been used to examine visual encoding strategies because eye gaze serves a functional role in memory formation and retrieval, independent from the hippocampus (Smith & Squire, 2017). Observers show similar eye movement patterns when encoding for implicit and explicit scene memories, such that they show more repetitive eye movements for old than foil new scenes, even when they do not behaviorally judge old and foil scenes to be different based on implicit memory (Ryals et al., 2015;Smith & Squire, 2017). These studies suggest that different task paradigms do not alter scene representations in memory, even when overt memory performance can be different.

3.2.2. Selective attention and sustained attentional state Selective attention toward specific items and the fluctuation of sustained attentional state during an encoding period are two ways attention affects memory. Selective attention prioritizes encoding certain aspects of scenes in working memory (Chun & Turk-Browne, 2007). Such prioritization is guided by prior memories, such that the memory areas in the brain (e.g., hippocampus and the MTL) are recruited in attention tasks (Castelhano & Witherspoon, 2016;Chun & Turk-Browne, 2007). In other words, memory and selective attention continue to affect each other, such that prior memory directs attention to certain scene aspects, and such selective attention determines what is to be encoded in future memory (Craik & Lockhart, 1972;Gazzaley & Nobre, 2012). On the other hand, regardless of prior experiences, observers better remember scenes encoded during a good attentional state than during a bad attentional state (deBettencourt et al., 2018). The sustained attentional state is often measured in a continuous performance task (CPT), where observers make trial judgments (e.g., indoor vs. outdoor) when viewing a series of scene images (90% are indoor and 10% are outdoor images). As a sequence of indoor scenes is shown, observers become habituated to quickly making the "indoor" judgment. The observers' reaction when a rare outdoor scene pops up is indicative of their sustained attentional states. When an outdoor scene appears, some observers may continue to make the habituated "indoor" judgment during a bad attentional state, whereas others may be able to slow down and make the correct judgment during a good attentional state. Observers may re-engage their attention upon making mistakes and start to slow down in their judgments. With this, a slower response time in a CPT signals a higher attentional state. Empirical research has demonstrated that higher attentional states in a CPT predict better scene recognition memory afterward, even when scenes are designed to be task-irrelevant during CPT (Corriveau et al., 2024;Swallow & Jiang, 2010). This means that regardless of selective attention and awareness of upcoming memory tests, more visual information can be encoded in general when observers achieve a good attentional state. Recent studies have demonstrated that sustained attentional state and scene memorability (see Section 2.1.3. Memorability) have independent impacts on memory (Wakeland-Hart et al., 2022). The two factors can be leveraged to maximize memory performance by showing memorable scenes during poor attentional states and forgettable scenes during good attentional states (Roberts et al., 2024). These results suggest that selective attention and sustained attentional state at task affect scene memory, and that prior knowledge is used to guide selective attention and scene memorability can be utilized to augment attentional state.

3.2.3. Mental imagery ability Mental imagery is the ability to represent certain visual information in the mind without any perceptual inputs (Dennett, 1991;Pylyshyn, 2002). Individual differences in mental imagery ability lead to different levels of vividness when the "mind's eye" sees a scene. In extreme cases, people with aphantasia cannot picture scenes in their minds, whereas people with hyperphantasia can mentally picture vivid scenes that are equivalent to real scenes (Milton et al., 2021;Zeman et al., 2020). Consequently, the brain may have adapted to different mental imagery abilities using different strategies to scaffold memory encoding and retrieval (Fan et al., 2023). For example, when planning routes, individuals who are better at mentally visualizing scenes (e.g., roads, buildings, and stores) along routes ("sceners") may rely on spatial mental images, whereas those who have less vivid mental imagery may recall schematic, map-based information ("mappers") (Brunec et al., 2018(Brunec et al., , 2019see review: Fan et al., 2023). Indeed, sceners and mappers have shown different gray matter volumes along the long axis of the hippocampus, which underpins the formation of fined-grained spatial representations (Brunec et al., 2018(Brunec et al., , 2019. Previously (in Section 3.1.3. Familiarity and expertise), we mentioned that London taxi drivers who have developed detailed map representations show an increase in the volume of the posterior hippocampus (pHPC) and a decrease in the volume of the anterior hippocampus (aHPC). Larger pHPC and smaller aHPC have also been found among regular mappers who mainly rely on cognitive maps during route planning, compared to sceners who rely on spatial scene imagery (Brunec et al., 2018). This suggests that people with varying abilities of mental imagery may develop different memory representations (map-based vs. image-based) of scenes.

3.2.4. Emotions Scenes containing emotional content (e.g., harmful objects or behaviors) affect observers' processing at task (Sugiura et al., 2009). In general, observers remember positive scenes (e.g., children blowing bubbles) more quickly and with more detail than neutral and negative scenes (e.g., house on fire) (Melcher, 2010). Compared to neutral images, negative images lead to better memory only when a certain negative object serves as the focus within a complex scene, such that observers' attention is drawn toward this emotionally salient object without being able to fully process the rest of the scene (Bouvarel et al., 2022). In contrast, when a scene contains no focal negative object but gives a negative impression overall, memory performance of such a negative scene does not exceed neutral scenes. Prior eye-tracking and fMRI studies demonstrated different processing between neutral and negative images that contained focal objects (Kuniecki et al., 2017). Observers fixated longer on objects than the background for negative images but not neutral images. A dozen studies have confirmed the key role of the amygdala in emotional scene encoding and retrieval, such that the amygdala shows enhanced activation when encoding and retrieving emotional scenes, compared to neutral scenes (see meta-analyses: (Dahlgren et al., 2020;Murty et al., 2010). When encoding emotional scenes, the amygdala mainly collaborates with the MTL (e.g., hippocampus), the VVS (e.g., scene processing areas), and potentially the PFC for top-down control. Overall, negative, focal objects can lead to better scene memory, and such emotional content has been shown to enhance neural activation during scene encoding.

3.2.5. Rewards Prior work shows mixed evidence on how associating rewards with stimuli affects memory. When observers make larger prediction errors as they learn to predict the amount of reward associated with each image in a scene sequence, they tend to better remember scenes in these error trials (Rouhani et al., 2018). This suggests that a way rewards affect memory is through reward prediction error, such that more surprising disparities between estimates and the actual rewards lead to better memory, regardless of the actual amount of rewards. Another way rewards affect memory is through its magnitude. Although behavioral and fMRI data reveal memory biases towards objects and scenes associated with higher amounts of monetary rewards (Schultz et al., 2022;Wimmer & Shohamy, 2012), it is unclear whether rewards further influence memory consolidation (Schultz et al., 2023). In other words, the beneficial effect of high rewards may happen transiently at encoding but not last for long-term memory processing. Rather than remembering items associated with higher rewards, observers seem to remember the reward magnitude better than the reward-associated items. In one study, observers encoded unique objects paired with repetitive scenes that were associated with high or low awards (Schultz et al., 2023). Results indicated that rewards only benefited scene memory when observers remembered the magnitude of rewards, and such beneficial effect did not spread to episodically paired images. Overall, higher reward prediction errors and magnitudes that are associated with a scene may trigger successful scene encoding, but further research is needed to fully understand the effect of rewards on long-term memory processing.

3.2.6. Naturalness of the physical environment Interestingly, the scene in which the observer is physically present when engaging in a memory task also affects the process of scene memory. Because scenes can be categorized as natural vs. manmade (urban), prior work examined how these different scene contexts affected one's emotions and memory (Schertz et al., 2022). Observers reported having more positive feelings and creative thoughts when walking in a nature conservatory (natural scene), compared to a mall (manmade scene). After physically interacting with nature, observers show better working memory performance (Berman et al., 2008;Bourrier et al., 2018;Bratman et al., 2012;Stenfors et al., 2019). This may be because a higher level of naturalness requires less divided attention to the environment (e.g., moving cars and people), and thus, more cognitive resources are available for encoding. Indeed, with fewer cognitive resources available, scene observers show more disrupted (less focused) patterns of eye movements, which is a proxy of memory encoding (Cronin et al., 2020). Therefore, encoding materials within a natural environment can lead to better memory.

3.3. Scene memory across the lifespan 3.3.1. Children Although children are able to remember scenes and objects during infancy and early childhood, further cognitive and neural developments through adulthood enable observers to encode more complex scenes in a more flexible manner. During early infancy, locomotive development of sitting, crawling, and walking drives the understanding of objects and scenes. At around five and six months, infants learn to sit without support, allowing them to look at a further distance and reach more interesting objects (Rochat & Goubet, 1995). By six and a half months old, infants start to memorize and identify at least one object at a time based on its perceptual features, suggesting that they can store at least one object representation in memory (Káldy & Leslie, 2005). However, such an object representation tends to be interfered with and overwritten by new objects. At nine months old, infants start to crawl and have more capacity to observe objects within a scene from different viewpoints. Through object reaching and crawling, infants may realize that object locations can be stable relative to one another despite the infants' own movements. In this way, by nine months of age, infants may develop allocentric scene representations (i.e., object locations in relation to one another) beyond an egocentric viewpoint (i.e., object locations in relation to oneself) (Gilmore & Johnson, 1997;Mullally & Maguire, 2014). Consequently, nine-month-old crawlers can recognize the same item across different scene backgrounds, but their non-crawling counterparts cannot (Herbert et al., 2007;Richmond & Nelson, 2009). This suggests that being able to move and explore within a scene allows infants to develop more flexible scene representations. Indeed, rudimentary hippocampal-dependent memory may have appeared at nine months, as infants start to bind object-space representations and develop allocentric spatial memory of scenes (Mullally & Maguire, 2014). By around fourteen months, children's locomotive and communicative muscles are in place to support walking and word production. The ability to walk and further explore exposes children to more objects and promotes the learning of scene knowledge, including object labels and relative locations. By age two, children become semantically and motorically more competent, such that they can combine words to produce sentences and walk more steadily. Prior work shows that two-year-olds are sensitive to object violations in scenes (e.g., toilet paper in a dishwasher), such that when an object is perceptually salient, they look longer at the object when it is incongruent within a scene, compared to when it is congruent (e.g., toilet paper in a holder within a bathroom) (Helo et al., 2017). This provides evidence that by age two, children have possessed initial scene grammar (see Section 2.1.1. Alignment with Scene Grammar) of "what" objects should go "where" and can readily extract knowledge from scene grammar at scene encoding (Öhlschläger & Võ, 2020). Although infants and young children can encode episodic memories, memories in the first three years of life are hard to recall in adulthood. This phenomenon is called "infantile amnesia," which has been observed both in humans and non-human animals (Alberini & Travaglia, 2017;Freud, 1983). Rodent's work demonstrated that the hippocampus undergoes neurogenesis early in infancy and decreases in neurogenesis when infantile amnesia dissipates (Alberini & Travaglia, 2017). The fading of infantile amnesia may signal functional competence of the hippocampus and the development of long-term memory encoding (Travaglia et al., 2016). Note that the hippocampus continues to develop in early childhood and well into adulthood (Uematsu et al., 2012). Under such a developmental trajectory, children can more accurately recognize object-scene associations as they age from three to five years old (Saragosa-Harris et al., 2021). Adults can recall some memories from early childhood, but their memories of preschool years (3-7 years old) often lack in number and details, a phenomenon called "childhood amnesia" (Hayne & Jack, 2011). Although young children's visual memory system is sensitive to similar scene properties as adults, their memories are prone to decay by adulthood. Eventually, young children can better remember the same images as adults by age four (Guo & Bainbridge, 2023), and similar to adults, they can remember a large set of object images with details (Ferrara et al., 2017). Nevertheless, the presence of childhood amnesia suggests that neural circuits underlying scene memories continue to develop into adulthood. Indeed, the main scene processing areas (PPA, OPA, and RSC) show different activation and connectivity patterns in a scene recognition test between children and adults, even for correct recognition trials (Chai et al., 2024). Prior fMRI work examining children, adolescents, and adults showed that the PPA, a scene-selective region, increases in volume across development (Golarai et al., 2007). In addition, the right posterior parahippocampal gyrus (PHG), which overlaps with the PPA and helps the retrieval of complex scenes (e.g., containing lots of objects), is not fully developed until early adulthood (Chai et al., 2010). As a result, although children and adolescents can recognize low-complexity scenes as well as adults, their accuracy in recognizing high-complexity scenes improves as they age. Overall, although infants and young children can develop detailed spatial representations of scenes, cognitive, language, and neural developments continue to promote their memory accuracy and flexible use of rich scene representations.

3.3.2. Older adults Despite the memory of single objects or scenes remaining relatively intact among older adults, aging is associated with decreased associative memory performance as a result of cognitive and neural decline (Bouffard et al., 2024). A recent study examining ages 18 through 85 discovered that starting in midlife, observers' memories of object-location associations decrease due to reduced abilities in representing different associations distinctively during memory encoding and retrieval rather than memory decay (Gellersen et al., 2024). There are a few pieces of evidence supporting fidelity reduction but not a memory decay account: (1) researchers find that object and location information are more tightly associated in long-term memory than short-term memory across different age groups. (2) When perceptual fidelity is less relevant to memory task performance (e.g., digit span or verbal learning tasks), aging has a limited impact on memory performance. (3) Higher perceptual distinctiveness (see Section 2.2.2. Perceptual Distinctiveness) between objects promotes recall of object-location associations. A previous fMRI study also finds that compared to younger adults, older adults exhibit reduced neural distinctiveness between trials when encoding object-house associations (Saverino et al., 2016) (Saverino 2016). These findings suggest that older adults are less able to develop specific representations for different associations at encoding, which creates difficulties for older adults in disambiguating different associative bindings at retrieval. A few studies have compared older adults' memories of objects and scenes. Older adults seem more susceptible to scene rather than object interference when asked to encode object-scene associations. Even when experimenters increased the perceptual distinctiveness between scenes from different object-scene pairs, older adults were still more likely to falsely recognize object-scene pairs than young adults (Bouffard et al., 2024). However, when objects were made more distinct across different object-scene pairs, older adults did not show greater false memory than young adults, suggesting that older adults may encode objects with higher fidelity than scenes, making it easier to disambiguate perceptually similar objects than scenes in memory. This does not mean that scenes predict memory decline among older adults better than objects. A study investigating older adults' abilities to differentiate previously encountered vs. new objects and scenes has provided evidence that hippocampal volume positively correlates with memory performance for object images but not for scene images (Stark & Stark, 2017). Additionally, compared to scene recognition performance, object recognition among older adults has been shown to better predict the development of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) that often accompanies memory decline (Fidalgo et al., 2016). Thus, although scene images can be helpful in detecting age-related memory decline, object images may better reflect neural changes due to aging. As a consequence of cognitive and neural decline, older adults have difficulties in binding objects with their location and scene information. Because of such age-related declines in associative memory, researchers may utilize associative memory tasks to predict stages of memory decline. Although object images have been used to detect memory-related neural decline among healthy people, complex scene stimuli have been more widely used to detect risks of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD), which is a major cause of dementia symptoms including difficulties in encoding new memories (Scheltens et al., 2021). Being able to detect genetic risk associated with AD before its onset is important because genetic factors predominantly contribute to the risk of AD. During scene encoding, healthy participants who carry an AD-causing mutation show hyperactivation in the MTL (Quiroz et al., 2015). Another study shows that performance in a spatial navigation game (Sea Hero Quest) can reliably distinguish adult carriers of AD-causing genes from non-carriers (Coughlan et al., 2019). With further investigation, scenes may be more widely used to detect heritable risks of AD among healthy individuals. Besides using scenes to detect genetic manifestation of AD, researchers have also utilized scenes to detect AD-related neural degradation. One study uses scenes to reflect differences between healthy adults and non-AD, healthy individuals who reported subjective cognitive decline (e.g., frequent memory loss), which can be symptoms preceding AD and dementia (Ruiz-Rizzo et al., 2022). At scene retrieval, healthy adults show better memory of scenes that contain more (vs. a few) objects, reflecting their abilities to maintain distinctive scene representations using unique scene details. In contrast, individuals reporting subjective cognitive decline perform similarly for scenes containing different numbers of objects, suggesting less distinctive scene representations. Prior work revealed that the MTL, a region important for scene perception and memory, shows early signs of memory degradation that relate to the development of hippocampal atrophy and mild cognitive impairment (MCI, an early stage of AD) (Dickerson & Sperling, 2008). Specifically, the MTL shows hyperactivation during scene memory tasks at early stages of MCI and becomes inactive during scene encoding as MCI symptoms exacerbate. Such hyperactivation may indicate functional incompetence of the MTL due to MCI and the need of dedicating more resources on scene processing, as MCI patients show worse memory performance despite heightened neural activity. Researchers have also found hyperactivation in scene-processing regions among MCI (MPA, PPA, and OPA) (Bai et al., 2023) and AD patients (hippocampus, PPA) (Hämäläinen et al., 2007;Kircher et al., 2007) during encoding, suggesting that scene images may be able to reflect neural atrophy along the AD trajectory. Notably, Bainbridge et al. (2019) discovered a set of scene images that are well remembered by healthy participants but not MCI patients. A follow-up study confirmed that MCI patients show higher activation in scene-processing regions (PPA, RSC, and OPA) when encoding diagnostic scenes, compared to non-diagnostic scenes, whereas healthy participants show similar neural activations across scene types (Bai et al., 2023). In general, scene stimuli have proved to be helpful in studying dementia, as individuals at different stages of the developmental trajectory of AD have shown classifiable sensitivity to scenes, compared to healthy adults. In sum, this section discussed observer-related factors that affect their scene memory. Section 3.1 demonstrated the importance of prior knowledge, including schema knowledge, prior visual statistics, and expertise, in affecting what visual information is remembered and left out. Section 3.2 introduced a selection of cognitive factors that may affect one's performance during memory tasks. Section 3.3 showed how age-related neural development and decline affect scene memories among infants, children, adolescents, adults across ages, and individuals with memory deficits. In the next section, we will discuss how scene-specific (Section 2) and observer-specific (Section 3) factors interact to form coherent scene knowledge in memory and to guide adaptive behaviors in real life.

div.head: Interaction between External (Stimulus-Level) and Internal (Observer-Level) Effects on
div.p: Visual Memory of Natural Scenes Sections 2 and 3 separately discuss stimulus-and observer-related properties that affect the visual memory of scenes, respectively. However, as humans maneuver through the world, visual inputs constantly interact with one's prior memory schemas to create and update map-like spatial representations, which guide humans' behavior at every moment. This section discusses the formation and updating of spatial representations in the mind and how such representations guide spatial navigation behaviors upon being encoded in memory. 4.1. Cognitive maps When visiting a grocery store for the first time, as an individual walks through the store, they develop internal representations of the store layout, consisting of different sections (e.g., fresh produce, meat section, bakery, etc.). When they visit a new grocery store consisting of the same sections with a different layout, they may construct another representation of the new store layout. These distinct representations of store layouts are cognitive maps, which depict unique, map-like spatial relations between (clusters of) objects of a specific grocery store (Epstein et al., 2017;Farzanfar et al., 2023;Tolman, 1948). Meanwhile, the individual may extract commonalities across the different store layouts to build general knowledge about grocery stores. For example, they may think that the produce and meat sections are always adjacent and that grocery stores are organized in grids with straight paths between aisles. Such commonalities drawn across distinct cognitive maps depicting similar environments (i.e., grocery stores) give rise to a spatial schema (see Section 3.1.1. Schema), which are abstract knowledge structures that are stored in memory and can be used to guide the formation of a future cognitive map (e.g., of a new grocery store) (Bartlett, 1995;Farzanfar et al., 2023;Gilboa & Marlatte, 2017). Note that distinct cognitive maps of different grocery stores are also stored in memory upon construction, such that they can be retrieved to guide navigation when one visits an old grocery store (see 4.2 Navigation for more details). The terms "cognitive map" and "schema" have also been used to represent non-spatial information (e.g., social cognitive maps, see Tavares et al., 2015; action schemas, e.g., reading is a possible action in a library, see Goodman, 1980). We will later discuss how semantic and spatial schema affect the formation of spatial cognitive maps, but before that, we will present some neuroimaging evidence proving the existence of cognitive maps that are different from the notion of schema. The neural underpinnings of cognitive maps was first found in rodents (Morris et al., 1982;O'Keefe & Dostrovsky, 1971) then among humans (Ekstrom et al., 2003). Specifically, place cells in the hippocampus fire at encoding to represent specific locations in space, suggesting the role of the hippocampus in forming spatial cognitive maps (Jeffery et al., 2004). A series of studies have also discovered other types of cells in the hippocampal complex that support cognitive map construction, including grid cells that encode distance (McNaughton et al., 2006), head direction (HD) cells that encode direction (Taube, 2007), and border and boundary cells (Byrne et al., 2007) that encode certain distance from a space boundary (Grieves & Jeffery, 2017). In fact, a larger right posterior hippocampus is associated with better learning of allocentric object relationships in both real (Schinazi et al., 2013) and artificial scenes (Hartley & Harlow, 2012) among both navigation experts (e.g., London taxi drivers, see Maguire et al., 2006; also see Section 3.1.3. Familiarity and expertise) and novices. More importantly, different sets of place cells fire for different spatial contexts, suggesting the construction of unique cognitive maps for different environments (Colgin et al., 2008). Even when the different environments share similar characteristics, the hippocampus undergoes the process of pattern separation to transform similar space representations to be highly dissimilar during encoding, which enables the construction of distinct cognitive maps for similar environments (Bakker et al., 2008;Chanales et al., 2017;Rolls, 2021;Yassa & Stark, 2011). These findings suggest that the construction of cognitive maps is not solely based on visual inputs, but also requires the retrieval of previous representations for comparison. Indeed, through continuous interactions between visual information and prior schematic knowledge, a cognitive map can be constantly updated upon construction. There is a lack of research providing direct evidence of the interactions between visual inputs and spatial schema, but visual inputs that violate semantic schema have been shown to cause greater processing difficulty of scenes and objects, compared to visual inputs that align with semantic schema. For instance, when an object is not semantically congruent with a scene (i.e., violates scene grammar, see Section 2.1.1. Alignment with scene grammar for more details) or cannot be associated conceptually with other objects in a scene (e.g., it is hard to integrate a fork with a bathroom scene), this semantically incongruent object taxes working memory, attention, and cognitive control during encoding (Brod et al., 2015). Importantly, Maxim and Brown (Maxim & Brown, 2023) pinpointed that though it is easy to indicate semantic schema violations (e.g., an object incongruent with a scene schema), what counts as a spatial schema violation is debatable.
