If one's spatial schema about living neighborhoods entails that routes in living neighborhoods are highly overlapped and free of obstacles, this individual may experience violations of the spatial schema when seeing a new neighborhood with non-overlapping routes or an obstacle that necessitates a detour. In face of such misalignments between visual information and memorized schemas, the observer would form a cognitive map of this new neighborhood by reconciling the misalignment either by updating the existing spatial schema of living neighborhoods, or by creating a new spatial schema to represent the new neighborhood (Armelin et al., 2017). This way, as visual information of an environment continues to be fed to the visual stream, there exists a bidirectional communication between the cognitive map and spatial schema. 4.2. Navigation Compared to the formation of cognitive maps, where visual inputs interact with schema knowledge, making decisions on navigational movements requires the interaction between visual inputs and cognitive maps that are retrieved from memory. To plan one's next paths, the first step is to anchor one's cognitive map with the physical space by aligning landmarks (relatively stable, permanent objects and boundaries, e.g., buildings, walls, etc.) (Epstein et al., 2017). Such alignment is mainly driven by scene-processing areas: the OPA processes action-related aspects of a scene, such as space boundaries and possible routes, the PPA identifies the scene context and landmarks, and the RSC anchors the cognitive map based on landmarks (Epstein, 2008;Nasr et al., 2011). In other words, the OPA and the PPA recognize landmarks from perceptual information, while the RSC matches physical landmarks to landmarks in the cognitive map. The second step of path planning is to compute the distance between one's physical location and the goal's location (Epstein et al., 2017). The hippocampal complex generates different paths and their distances, with the help of the PFC, which seems to facilitate the interactions between visual information and the cognitive map. For example, the PFC shows heightened activations during route replanning in face of a detour. In this process, the PFC has been shown to reduce processing load by grouping irrelevant parts of the environment into clusters (Balaguer et al., 2016). Therefore, although it may seem like route planning of a single step relies solely on the interaction between visual inputs and the cognitive map, this is not the case, as spatial schema from memory is used to constantly monitor action and path feasibility. Upon choosing a route, the third step is to convert the 2D map-like route into a 3D representation (Buchanan & Tranel, 2008). The 2D route representation of the cognitive map refers to an allocentric representation of relative distances between objects, without considering where the observer is positioned in the scene (Klatzky, 1998). However, moving in a physical space requires egocentric coding, where objects' locations are represented relative to one's location. Once the viewpoint is adjusted, one may start marching towards the goal location. Note that humans maintain both egocentric and allocentric representations in mind and may choose one or combine both representations based on task demands (Burgess, 2006) and individual preferences (see Mental imagery subsection under Section 3.2). These results demonstrate that every movement in spatial navigation relies on a multi-step process, where each step entails close interactions between external information of the physical environment and internal computations using the cognitive map, which is stored in memory and relies on memory to update its information. Consequently, navigational processes can be affected by stimulus-level and personal factors. High environmental details and complexity can negatively affect the formation and updates of cognitive maps (Maxim & Brown, 2023). That is, when an environment contains more details and clusters, navigators' attention may be captured by details irrelevant to route planning. At an individual level, stress has also been shown to negatively affect scene recall (Buchanan & Tranel, 2008) and navigation abilities (Gagnon et al., 2019). Under time pressure, navigators show reduced accuracy in wayfinding because stress disengages the hippocampus, which underlies the generation of potential routes during route planning. There are also individual differences in navigation abilities, such that individuals with larger working memory capacities are more proficient in constructing cognitive maps (Weisberg & Newcombe, 2016). Individuals who better maintain scene details (e.g., specific landmarks) in memories also tend to maintain distinct representations of nonoverlapping routes in a neighborhood, whereas those who have smaller working memory capacities tend to merge representations of different routes. These results again highlight the interactive nature of external and internal information that enables adaptive navigational behaviors. This section showed how external visual information interacts with internal schema knowledge to create spatial representations that guide physical movements. Section 4.1 introduced how cognitive maps are formed in memory by reconciling misalignments between visual and schema information. Section 4.2 introduced the mechanism of route planning using cognitive maps from memory, again demonstrating external and internal factors on scene memory in real life.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In the past two decades, the use of clever psychophysical paradigms, neuroimaging, and computational techniques has provided more insights into how the visual system encodes scenes and represents spatial environments. These studies reveal both stimulus-and individual-level effects on scene memory, suggesting constant communications between sensory and cognitive information when processing spatial contents. In Section 2, we presented how scene encoding is affected by scene-level properties, both originating from a specific scene and cross-scene comparisons. In Section 3, we delved into how scene encoding can be affected by cognitive knowledge accumulated before encoding, cognitive states prompted during the encoding task, and age-related cognitive abilities. In Section 4, we discussed how the interactions between scene-level visual inputs and individual-level cognitive knowledge update spatial knowledge and enable spatial navigation in the physical world.

div.head: MEMORY OF NATURAL SCENES
div.p: Although we have gained some understanding of the memory encoding of scenes, many questions are yet to be answered. At the stimulus level, it is not fully clear why humans consistently remember (the memorability effect) and falsely remember (the Visual Mandela Effect, see Prasad & Bainbridge, 2022) certain scenes more than others, regardless of individual differences. Although scenes have been shown to scaffold memory encoding of object stimuli (cite), it is unclear what scene properties underlie the scaffolding benefits. At the observer level, future studies can examine how the different cognitive factors work together to affect scene encoding, how individual differences play a role in each process, and what happens when scene encoding is a secondary task. By understanding how scene encoding fails in these processes, researchers may be better able to translate memory findings to more ecologically valid settings. When looking at the communications between stimulus-and observer-level information, although researchers have proposed several theories, including the route planning theory we mentioned in Section 4.2, it remains unclear how neural and cognitive activities give rise to navigational behaviors. Future studies could continue to probe how visual input and cognitive processes give rise to neural activities that construct new knowledge in memory, and how such new memory enables behavioral responses and further affects cognitive processes. In sum, visual memory encoding of natural scenes is a multifaceted process that requires constant integration and reconciliation of external and internal information. Researchers have started to depict a more coherent picture of scene processing and propose theories on cognitive and neural mechanisms that give rise to adaptive navigational behaviors. These explorations will continue to shed light on how humans' visual system works as an interface between our external and internal worlds.
